facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 853 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 853 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 9th August 1961 of Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 86 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 9th August, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 86 of 1957.

facts.text: Reference made under Section 66(1) of Indian Income Tax Act 1922 by Income Tax Appellate Tribunal Madras.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by certificate of the High Court of Madras, is directed against its judgment in a reference made to it under S. 66 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

facts.text: Question referred: whether assessment of income of assessee other than salary as individual and not as HUF till 11th December 1952 for AY 1953-54 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred to was whether the assessment of the income of the assessee, other than his salary in the hands of the assessee, as an individual and number as a Hindu undivided family till 11th December, 1952, for the assessment year 1953-54 is valid.

facts.text: Assessee is youngest son of T.V. Sundaram Ayyangar who was Karta of HUF consisting of number of persons.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is the youngest son of T. V. Sundaram Ayyangar, who was the Karta of a Hindu undivided family companysisting of a number of persons.

facts.text: Partial partition of family: 150 shares of Rs.1000 each in T.V. Sundaram Iyengar and Sons Limited divided equally among coparceners, assessee got 25 shares of Rs.25,000.

anchor.surface_text: There was a partial partition of the above family and 150 shares of Rs. 1,000 each in T. V. Sundaram Iyengar and sons Limited, a private limited companypany, were divided equally among the companyarceners, the assessee getting 25 shares of the value of 25,000.

facts.text: Assessee acquired house properties, shares and deposits up to March 31, 1952 with shares as nucleus.

anchor.surface_text: With the aforesaid shares as nucleus, the assessee acquired houseproperties, shares and deposits up to March 31, 1952.

facts.text: Assessee was Service Manager of the private limited company and received substantial remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: As the assessee was also the Service Manager of the aforesaid private limited companypany, he also received substantial remuneration.

facts.text: First son Venugopal born to assessee on December 11, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The first son, named Venugopal, was born to the assessee on December 11, 1952

facts.text: Conception of child took place sometime in March 1952 (common ground).

anchor.surface_text: and it is companymon ground that the companyception of the child must have taken place sometime in March, 1952.

facts.text: For assessment year 1952-53, assessee assessed as individual with all sources of income.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1952-53, the assessee was assessed as an individual with reference to all his sources of income.

facts.text: For AY 1953-54 (accounting year April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953), assessee claimed income from all sources except salary assessed as HUF consisting of himself and son, came into existence in March 1952 when conceived.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1953-54  accounting year April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953  the assessee claimed that income from all sources, except salary, should be assessed in the hands of H.U.F., companysisting of himself and his son Venugopal, which according to him had companye into existence in or about March 1-952 when Venugopal was companyceived.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer recognized HUF only from date of birth December 11, 1952, admitting male child acquires coparcenary rights from conception but only inter se members, not vs State.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer, while admitting that a male child acquires companyarcenary rights in the family even from the date of his companyception, companysidered that this proposition applied only as far as the minors rights inter se other members were companycerned, and as far as the claims of the State or outsiders were companycerned, he thought that an unborn son would number companye into the picture. therefore, he recognised the family only from the date of the birth of the child, viz., December 11, 1952.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO's view.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld his view

facts.text: Assessee failed before Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and the assessee also failed before the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Madras High Court answered the question against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the assessee.

facts.text: Counsel for assessee contends HUF exists from conception per Hindu law principles applicable to Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned companynsel for the assessee, companytends that under the Act Hindu undivided family is a separate unit and in determining whether a Hindu undivided family exists or number, and if it exists, from what date it has companye into being, regard must be had to the principles of Hindu Law

facts.text: Attorney-General for Revenue does not dispute Hindu law doctrine but says it applies only for special purpose safeguarding son's property rights, not universal, and for tax needs visible reality.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General, who appears on behalf of the Revenue, does number dispute the existence of the doctrine of Hindu Law relied on by Mr. Sastri, but says that this doctrine applies only for a special purpose,, the purpose being to safeguard the rights of the son to property, and that Hindu Law itself recognises that this doctrine is number of universal application.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment by Sikri J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that answer to question is in favour of revenue.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in favour of the revenue.

facts.text: Alternative contention by assessee that status at end of accounting year determines HUF, not raised before lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri companytends in the alternative that what we are companycerned with is the status at the end of the accounting year and that at least in this case where the child was in existence at the end of the accounting year, the status would be that of Hindu undivided family. This point was number raised before

facts.text: Accounting year for AY 1953-54 is April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: accounting year April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953

facts.text: Income Tax Officer required to issue notice under s.22 for returns.

anchor.surface_text: At the relevant time, under s. 22 of, the Act, the Income Tax Officer was required to give numberice by publication in the press and by publication in the prescribed manner, requiring every person whose total income in the previous year exceeded the maximum amount which is number chargeable to income tax

facts.text: Prescribed return form for HUF requires names, ages of members at end of previous year.

anchor.surface_text: Part IIIA of the prescribed form required the following particulars to be filled up in the case of a Hindu undivided family ----------------------------------------------------------- Serial Name of members of the Relationship Age at Remarks No. family at the end of the the end previous year who were of the entitled to claim parti- previous tion. year

facts.text: In C.B.C. Deshmukh v. I. Mallappa Chanbasappa, Supreme Court held doctrine of son in womb not applicable to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: In C. B. C. Deshmukh v. l. Mallappa Chahbasappa 1  this Court had occasion to companysider the scope of the doctrine that A.I.R. 1964 S.C. 510. under Hindu Law a son companyceived or in his mothers womb is equal in many respects to a son actually in existence in the matter of inheritance, partition, survivorship and the right to impeach an alienation made by his father. But this Court refused to extend it to adoption.
under S. 66 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act, by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras.

issues.text: whether the assessment of the income of the assessee, other than his salary in the hands of the assessee, as an individual and not as a Hindu undivided family till 11th December, 1952, for the assessment year 1953-54 is valid

anchor.surface_text: The question referred to was whether the assessment of the income of the assessee, other than his salary in the hands of the assessee, as an individual and number as a Hindu undivided family till 11th December, 1952, for the assessment year 1953-54 is valid.

issues.text: whether this doctrine of Hindu Law can be applied for the purpose of determining the coming into being of a Hindu undivided family as an assessable entity

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises is whether this doctrine of Hindu Law can be applied for the purpose of determining the companying into being of a Hindu undivided family as an assessable entity.

issues.text: in determining whether a Hindu undivided family exists or not, and if it exists, from what date it has come into being, regard must be had to the principles of Hindu Law

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned counsel for the assessee, contends that under the Act Hindu undivided family is a separate unit and in determining whether a Hindu undivided family exists or not, and if it exists, from what date it has come into being, regard must be had to the principles of Hindu Law for the Act does not lay down any principles regarding this matter.

issues.text: this doctrine applies only for a special purpose, the purpose being to safeguard the rights of the son to property, and that Hindu Law itself recognises that this doctrine is not of universal application

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General, who appears on behalf of the Revenue, does not dispute the existence of the doctrine of Hindu Law relied on by Mr. Sastri, but says that this doctrine applies only for a special purpose, the purpose being to safeguard the rights of the son to property,

issues.text: under the Act the person to whom income accrues must be a visible reality

anchor.surface_text: and that Hindu Law itself recognises that this doctrine is not of universal application. He urges, in the alternative, that at any rate the Act is concerned with realities under the Act the person to whom income accrues must be a visible reality, and, he says, the only visible person who existed up to December 11, 1952, was the assessee.

issues.text: what we are concerned with is the status at the end of the accounting year and that at least in this case where the child was in existence at the end of the accounting year, the status would be that of Hindu undivided family

even if a Hindu undivided family was in existence towards the end of the accounting year, still the whole income received or accrued in the accounting year did not thereby become the assessable income of the Hindu undivided family

arguments.claim: In determining whether a Hindu undivided family exists or not, and if it exists, from what date it has come into being, regard must be had to the principles of Hindu Law as the Act does not lay down any principles regarding this matter

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned counsel for the assessee, contends that under the Act Hindu undivided family is a separate unit and in determining whether a Hindu undivided family exists or not, and if it exists, from what date it has come into being, regard must be had to the principles of Hindu Law

arguments.court_response: The doctrine does not fit in with the scheme of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In C. B. C. Deshmukh v. l. Mallappa Chahbasappa this Court had occasion to consider the scope of the doctrine that under Hindu Law a son conceived or in his mothers womb is equal in many respects to a son actually in existence in the matter of inheritance, partition, survivorship

arguments.claim: Doctrine of Hindu Law cannot be applied for determining coming into being of HUF as assessable entity; does not fit scheme of Act

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises is whether this doctrine of Hindu Law can be applied for the purpose of determining the coming into being of a Hindu undivided family as an assessable entity. As this Court held in C. B. C. Deshmukh v. l. Mallappa Chanbasappa

arguments.claim: Under sections 3 and 4, income accrues or arises to existing persons/entities; cannot accrue to non-existing HUF

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act charges the total income of the previous year of every individual, Hindu undivided family, company and local authority, Section 4 includes in the total income of any person all income, profits and gains... which accrue or arise or are deemed to accrue or arise to him

arguments.claim: Provisions of s.22 and return forms incompatible with unborn son; would create filing anomalies

anchor.surface_text: At the relevant time, under s. 22 of, the Act, the Income Tax Officer was required to give notice... Part IIIA of the prescribed form required... Name of members of the family at the end of the previous year... Age at the end of the previous year

arguments.claim: Even if HUF existed at end of year, income accrued earlier belongs to assessee; Act disregards subsequent application

anchor.surface_text: The Act disregards subsequent application of income and profits once they have arisen. When the income and profits arose, they belonged to the assessee, as no Hindu undivided family was then in existence.

arguments.claim: Recognising HUF from birth does not affect son's rights; no intention to impose tax liability on unborn

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the difficulty of reconciling this doctrine with the scheme of the Act, Mr. Sastri has not been able to satisfy us that any rights of the son are being affected by not recognising his existence for the purposes of s. 3 of the Act till he is actually born. Income-tax is a liability

holdings.text: The assessment of the income of the assessee, other than his salary, as an individual and not as a Hindu undivided family till 11th December 1952, for the assessment year 1953-54 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in favour of the revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hindu law doctrine of coparcenary rights from conception does not apply to income tax assessment as HUF must exist as visible entity when income accrues under ss 3 and 4; incompatible with return filing provisions and scheme of Act.

holdings.text: The doctrine of Hindu law that a son conceived or in womb is equal to born son in coparcenary rights is not of universal application and applies mainly for determining property rights and safeguarding son's interests.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises is whether this doctrine of Hindu Law can be applied for the purpose of determining the coming into being of a Hindu undivided family as an assessable entity. As this Court held in C. B. C. Deshmukh v. l. Mallappa Chanbasappa

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Deshmukh case limits doctrine to secular property matters like inheritance, partition; refused extension to adoption to avoid anomalies.

holdings.text: The Hindu law doctrine does not fit the scheme of the Income Tax Act and Legislature did not intend to incorporate it for determining HUF as assessable entity.

anchor.surface_text: the doctrine is not of universal application and it applies mainly for the purpose of determining rights to property and safeguarding such rights of the son. It seems to us that this doctrine does not fit in with the scheme of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme under ss 3, 4 requires income to accrue to existing individual or HUF; doctrine creates anomalies in notice, returns, assessment.

holdings.text: Under sections 3 and 4 of the Act, income accrues or arises to an existing person or entity; it cannot accrue to a non-existent HUF before the son's birth.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act charges the total income of the previous year of every individual, Hindu undivided family, company and local authority, Section 4 includes in the total income of any person all income, profits and gains... which accrue or arise or are deemed to accrue or arise to him

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax charge and total income scope presuppose existence of assessee at time of accrual; daily accrual cannot belong to unborn entity.

holdings.text: Provisions of s 22 and prescribed HUF return forms are incompatible with recognizing an unborn son as member, creating assessment anomalies.

anchor.surface_text: At the relevant time, under s. 22 of, the Act, the Income Tax Officer was required to give notice by publication in the press and by publication in the prescribed manner... Part IIIA of the prescribed form required... Name of members of the family at the end of the previous year

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice requires furnishing by existing persons; form demands names, ages at year-end of entitled members, impossible for unborn child.

holdings.text: Even if HUF existed at end of accounting year, income accrued or received before birth belongs to assessee as individual, not HUF.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Income taxed based on entity to which it accrued at time of arising; subsequent HUF formation does not retroactively change ownership.

holdings.text: The Act disregards subsequent application of income and profits once they have arisen to the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The Act disregards subsequent application of income and profits once they have arisen. When the income and profits arose, they belonged to the assessee, as no Hindu undivided family was then in existence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Birth of son creates HUF but does not displace prior accrual to individual; tax liability fixed at accrual time.

holdings.text: Recognizing HUF from birth does not affect son's property rights or impose tax liability on unborn persons.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the difficulty of reconciling this doctrine with the scheme of the Act, Mr. Sastri has not been able to satisfy us that any rights of the son are being affected by not recognising his existence for the purposes of s. 3 of the Act till he is actually born.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income tax is pecuniary liability on existing persons; no legislative intent for fiction extending to taxation of embryo.
